silhouette.shapes
Class CanvasShape

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--silhouette.constraints.constrainedObject
        |
        +--silhouette.shapes.AbstractSilShape
              |
              +--silhouette.shapes.BoxShape
                    |
                    +--silhouette.shapes.CompositeShape
                          |
                          +--silhouette.shapes.CanvasShape
All Implemented Interfaces:
SilContainer, SilShape
Direct Known Subclasses:
ColorPaletteCanvas
public class CanvasShape
extends CompositeShape
implements SilContainer

CanvasShape is a Composite Shape that can display Silhouette shapes. Displaying Silhouette objects using a CanvasShape is a two step process:

  1. Like a Swing component, a CanvasShape must be added to some type of Swing container object. Typically this object will be a JPanel, such as the ContentPane of a JFrame. However, a CanvasShape is not a JComponent, so it cannot be directly added to a Swing container object. Instead, every CanvasShape contains an instance of a JPanel and this instance must be added to a Swing container. The JPanel instance can be retrieved using the CanvasShape's getSilPanel command.
  2. Silhouette shapes must be added to a CanvasShape using one of CanvasShape's add methods.

Silhouette supports a 2.5 dimensional graphics model, which means that objects are drawn from back to front using two criteria:

  1. An object's level number is the first criterium used to determine where an object is drawn. Objects with smaller level numbers are drawn on top of objects with smaller level numbers. If an object is not explicitly assigned a level number by an add method, then it is assigned a default level number, which is defined by the CanvasShape.DefaultDepth constant. Silhouette also defines a CanvasShape.FeedbackDepth level number, which is the level number that should be assigned to feedback objects. The FeedbackDepth number is less than the DefaultDepth number so feedback objects are drawn on top of normal objects.

  2. If two objects have the same level number, then they are drawn in the order in which they are stored in a list maintained for that level. Objects are drawn from front to back on the list, which means that objects which appear later in the list will be drawn above objects which appear earlier in the list. When objects are added to a CanvasShape, they are added to the end of the level's list unless the programmer specifies otherwise. The add methods provide a way to insert an object at a certain index position in the list. The sendToBack and bringToFront methods provide ways to move objects to the bottom or top of the drawing order for that level after the objects have been added to the CanvasShape.

By default, Silhouette clears and redraws the entire display when an object is damaged. This seems to work fine on most of today's high-speed workstations and PCs. However, if the programmer wants to use a more sophisticated redraw algorithm, the programmer can write a class that extends the DisplayManager interface and then provide an instance of this class to the constructor for CanvasShape.

zLevels

protected silhouette.properties.zList zLevels
A list of z-depths for the canvas. Each z-depth contains a list of objects at that depth.

selectedObjects

protected java.util.List selectedObjects
The list of selected objects on this canvas. This variable is provided for the convenience of the application programmer as a way to keep track of selected objects.

The SilPanel which the CanvasShape is attached to
